Work is ongoing on the '''eastern span replacement of the [[San FranciscoâOakland Bay Bridge]]'''. The new eastern span is currently scheduled to open to traffic by 2013 at an estimated cost of $6.3 billion.<ref>[http://www.baybridgeinfo.org/faqs San Francisco - Oakland Bay Bridge Project - FAQs] from http://www.baybridgeinfo.org {{WebCite|url=http://www.webcitation.org/5Qa2AnVni|date =2007-07-24}}</ref> The original San FranciscoâOakland Bay Bridge, built in 1936, became the subject of concern after a section collapsed during the [[Loma Prieta earthquake]] on October 17, 1989. Therefore, a replacement span was required so it can withstand the next large earthquake. This new eastern span is supposed to last at least another 150 years,<ref>[http://baybridge360.org Click on the top orange circle (March 2011). The guy said that the new bridge will stand for 150 years]</ref> way past several large earthquakes, or at least while cars are still on the road. As of March 2011, the SAS tower needs only its completion cap and cable saddle which will be lifted next week, while sections of deck structure will be emplaced later.
+
Work is ongoing on the '''eastern span replacement of the [[San FranciscoâOakland Bay Bridge]]'''. The new eastern span is currently scheduled to open to traffic by 2013 at an estimated cost of $6.3 billion.<ref>[http://www.baybridgeinfo.org/faqs San Francisco - Oakland Bay Bridge Project - FAQs] from http://www.baybridgeinfo.org {{WebCite|url=http://www.webcitation.org/5Qa2AnVni|date =2007-07-24}}</ref> The original San FranciscoâOakland Bay Bridge, built in 1936, became the subject of concern after a section collapsed during the [[Loma Prieta earthquake]] on October 17, 1989. Therefore, a replacement span was required so it can withstand the next large earthquake. This new eastern span is supposed to last at least another 150 years,<ref>[http://baybridge360.org Click on the top orange circle (March 2011). The guy said that the new bridge will stand for 150 years]</ref>. As of March 2011, the SAS tower needs only its completion cap and cable saddle which will be lifted next week, while sections of deck structure will be emplaced later.
